[[File:Blossermerrill2.jpg|left|thumb|100px]] [[File:Merrillblossernappanee.jpg|right|thumb|350px|The young Merrill Blosser in [[Nappanee, Indiana]].]] '''Merrill Blosser''' (May 28, 1892 – January 9, 1983) was the creator of the [[comic strip]] ''[[Freckles and His Friends]]'', which had a long run (1915–71).<ref name=evening>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=950&dat=19450920&id=Oo8LAAAAIBAJ&sjid=GVUDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4337,3383747 "Freckles and His Friends' is 30 Years Old" ''Evening Independent'', September 20, 1945.]</ref> Although his strip was set in the small town of Shadyside, it was obviously based on Blosser's hometown of [[Nappanee, Indiana]], since Blosser often referenced real Nappanee locations, such as Johnson's Drug Store.<ref>[http://www.luciefield.net/blosserlinks.html Lucie's Genealogy: Blosser Information]</ref> Six successful cartoonists lived in Nappanee as children, including [[Fred Neher]] (''[[Life’s Like That]]'') and [[Bill Holman (cartoonist)|Bill Holman]] (''[[Smokey Stover]]'').<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=Vqa3S-HlqkoC&pg=PA75&lpg=PA75&dq=%22Freckles+and+His+Friends%22&source=web&ots=-qf3c3nUBH&sig=T3godybIg1Kg9pewOt9oIh8dP8w&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=10&ct=result#PPA75,M1 Cavinder, Fred D. ''More Amazing Tales from Indiana''. Indiana University Press, 2003.]</ref>
Growing up in Nappanee, where he was born, Blosser was encouraged by his parents to take drawing lessons, and he signed up for [[Charles N. Landon]]'s correspondence course. When Blosser was 12 years old, ''National Magazine'' held a writing competition, and he was a winner with his essay, "The Best Way to Spend $300." The prize was a trip to Washington, D.C.
Touring the city, the prizewinners were taken to the White House to meet President [[Theodore Roosevelt]]. Lagging behind, Blosser drew a sketch of Roosevelt which prompted the President to exclaim, "Bully!" He then kept Blosser with him for half a day, advising him to continue in the field of art.<ref name=albertan/> Expelled from high school after he displayed caricatures of the high school faculty, including a drawing of the school principal as Satan, Blosser described the suspension as "the best break I ever had."
While attending Blue Ridge College in [[Union Bridge, Maryland]], in 1911, Blosser sold drawings to the ''[[Frederick News-Post|Frederick News]]'' in [[Frederick, Maryland]]. When he was 20, he quit school after selling a cartoon to the ''[[Baltimore News-American|Baltimore American]]'' in 1912. Blosser studied at the [[School of the Art Institute of Chicago|Chicago Academy of Fine Arts]]. He did cartoons for Chicago's ''Motor-Cycling'' magazine and magazines at the Denton Publishing Company in Cleveland, and he also drew political cartoons for the ''Wheeling Register'' and ''[[The Plain Dealer]]''.
==''Freckles and His Friends''== [[File:Frecklesandhis122147.jpg|right|thumb|550px|Merrill Blosser's ''Freckles and His Friends'' and ''Hector'' (December 21, 1947)]] Landon was also an editor at [[United Media|Newspaper Enterprise Association]], and in May 1915, he hired Blosser to work at NEA. Blosser was 23 when he began in the NEA art department, initially doing cartoons based on news events and then drawing five daily panels. One of these, titled ''Freckles'', began as a one-column daily gag panel on August 16, expanding into a full comic strip on September 20 when it was retitled ''Freckles and His Friends''. One by one, each of the other panels were dropped.
In July 1916, Blosser started another strip, ''Miniature Movies'', which evolved into ''Chestnut Charlie'', continuing until early in 1918 when Blosser concentrated exclusively on ''Freckles and His Friends''.<ref name=albertan>[http://ilovecomix.myjungledisk.com/ilovecomix/Comic%20Archives/Comic%20Strips/F/Freckles/FrecklesHistory.jpg ''The Albertan'', October 3, 1945.]</ref><ref name="Amazing">{{cite book | last = Cavinder | first = Fred D. | title = More Amazing Tales from Indiana | publisher = Indiana University Press | year = 2003 | pages = 75 |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Vqa3S-HlqkoC&pg=PA75 | isbn = 0-253-21653-2}}</ref>
==Life in Arcadia== Blosser married shortly after he drew the earliest ''Freckles and His Friends'' strips. For years, the couple lived in Cleveland, where the NEA office was located, until they moved in 1927 to Los Angeles. During the early 1940s, they lived at 751 Masselin Avenue before moving to the Los Angeles suburb of [[Arcadia, California|Arcadia]]. Asked about his activities away from his drawing table, Blosser responded that he "travels, swims, and lives a simple life." A 1945 syndicated newspaper profile of Blosser described his life in Arcadia during the 1940s: :Blosser had a beautiful home built to his own ideas. He has his own studio there and does all his work at home. He likes to raise flowers and vegetables, but he doesn't like to mow lawns, so he planted his front yard in variegated ivy instead of grass. It worked out fine. He is youthful, friendly and enthusiastic. He likes the outdoors, loves football games, long automobile rides and kids. He admires good art work and is a collector of fine paintings.<ref name=evening/><ref name=albertan/>
Blosser, who said he aimed for "simply good humor," was influenced by cartoonist [[Walter Hoban]] (''Jerry on the Job''). After his first few decades of doing the strip, Blosser shared the work with [[Henry Formhals]], who began as Blosser's assistant in 1935. Eventually, Blosser drew the [[Sunday strip]]s, while Formhals, beginning in 1938, drew the [[daily strip]]s. The last daily strip signed by Blosser was on February 12, 1966. Daily strips between February 14 and March 19 have Formhals' signature covered with opaque white. The March 21, 1966, daily strip is the first to carry Formhals' signature.<ref>[http://library.syr.edu/digital/guides/b/blosser_m.htm Syracuse University Special Collections: Merrill Blosser]</ref>
==Awards== Although the characters in the strip never joined up with the military during [[World War II]], Blosser's use of the strip to promote the sale of War Bonds brought him a personal citation from Secretary of the Treasury [[Henry Morgenthau, Jr.]]<ref>"Freckles to Retire", ''Lawton Constitution'' (Lawton, Oklahoma) August 27, 1971.</ref>
In New York in May, 1965, the [[National Cartoonists Society]] held a testimonial dinner honoring Blosser. The NCS gave him an award "in recognition of the wholesome entertainment he has brought his myriad readers" and for the creation of "the oldest regular comic strip still piloted by its creator."<ref>[http://yesteryear.clunette.com/nappanee6.html Morehead, Toni. "The Nappanee Six: Hoosiers with National Exposure", Yesteryear in Print.]</ref>
The following year, Blosser retired, and Formhals then worked alone on ''Freckles and His Friends'' from 1966 to 1971. The strip was discontinued on August 28, 1971. For most of his life, Blosser lived in Arcadia and [[Pasadena, California]], where he died in 1983.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.luciefield.net/blosserlinks.html Blosser family of Nappanee Indiana] *[http://lambiek.net/artists/b/blosser_merrill.htm Lambiek: Merrill Blosser]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Blosser, Merrill}} [[Category:1892 births]] [[Category:1983 deaths]] [[Category:People from Nappanee, Indiana]] [[Category:American comic strip cartoonists]] [[Category:Date of death missing]] [[Category:People from Union Bridge, Maryland]]

'''Miguel Gil Moreno de Mora''' (June 21, 1967 – May 24, 2000) was a [[Spain|Spanish]] cameraman and [[war correspondent]], working for [[Associated Press]].
After a successful career as a corporate [[lawyer]] in Barcelona, Spain, Miguel became a [[freelance]] [[war correspondent]] first in [[Sarajevo]] and later, an award winning cameraman for [[Associated Press Television News|AP Television]].
Leaving behind his career as a corporate lawyer in Spain, Miguel became a freelance war correspondent in Sarajevo and later in Kosovo, where he was one of the few Western cameraman to stay in [[Pristina]] during the Nato air campaign. His images of Albanians being herded on to railway carriages changed our understanding of what was happening in [[Kosovo]].
After that, he went to [[Grozny]] ([[Chechnya]]). His pictures from [[Chechnya]] were the people of [[Grozny]]'s only window to the world. He also was in [[Democratic Republic of the Congo|Congo]], [[Liberia]], [[Ruanda]], [[Sudan]] and [[Sierra Leone]]. However, as he wrote himself, he experienced the most dangerous moments of his life in [[Chechnya]]. Miguel's images were some of the few informative documents registered by an international agency in that conflict.
Miguel was awarded as cameraman of the year by the Royal Television Society in 2000, recognizing its outstanding job in conflict areas.
Miguel Gil Moreno de Mora and Reuters Correspondent [[Kurt Schork]] were shot to death in an [[ambush]] to a [[Sierra Leone Army]] (SLA) convoy by the fighters of the [[Revolutionary United Front]] on May 24, 2000. In the attack four SLA soldiers were killed and two other journalists, [[South Africa]]n cameraman Mark Chisholm and [[Greece|Greek]] photographer [[Yannis Behrakis]], were injured.<ref name="Report 25-05-2000">{{cite web|url=http://www.ifex.org/sierra_leone/2000/05/25/two_journalists_killed_by_ruf_gunmen/|title=Two journalists killed by RUF gunmen; two others wounded|date=2000-05-25|work=[[Committee to Protect Journalists|CPJ]]|publisher=[[International Freedom of Expression Exchange|IFEX]]|accessdate=2009-05-20}}</ref>
Miguel, 32, was "a big man — big of heart," in the words of AP photographer Santiago Lyon.
== From Miguel's Mother ==
“Miguel was a truly extraordinary person, as a son, a brother, as everything. Miguel fought all his life for his ideals and has died for them. He lived the stories he covered, because he felt his mission was to give voice to those who did not have one”. “I am filled with overwhelming sadness and grief, but in the end I find solace in the fact that Miguel was doing the job he loved and died doing the work he felt ordained for”.
== References == {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.fundacionmiguelgilmoreno.com Miguel Gil Moreno Foundation] * [http://www.ksmemorial.com/miguel.htm Miguel Gil Moreno Memorial]
{{authority control}}

revision.comment: /* Neurodegenerative diseases */[[User:JCW-CleanerBot#Logic|task]], replaced: Neurobiol Aging. → Neurobiol Aging
revision.text:
A '''minigene''' is a minimal gene fragment that includes an [[exon]] and the control regions necessary for the gene to express itself in the same way as a [[wild type]] gene fragment. This is a minigene in its most basic sense. More complex minigenes can be constructed containing multiple exons and [[Introns|intron(s)]]. Minigenes provide a valuable tool for researchers evaluating [[RNA splicing|splicing]] patterns both ''[[in vivo]]'' and ''[[in vitro]]'' biochemically assessed experiments.<ref name=Stoss /><ref name=Cooper /> Specifically, minigenes are used as splice reporter [[Vector (molecular biology)|vectors]] (also called [[Exon trapping|exon-trapping]] vectors) and act as a probe to determine which factors are important in splicing outcomes. They can be constructed to test the way both [[cis-regulatory element]]s (RNA effects) and [[trans-regulatory element]]s (associated [[proteins]]/[[splicing factor]]s) affect gene expression.<ref name=Desviat>{{cite journal|last=Desviat|first=LR|last2=Pérez|first2=B|last3=Ugarte|first3=M|title=Minigenes to confirm exon skipping mutations|journal=Methods Mol. Biol.|year=2012|volume=867|page=37|doi=10.1007/978-1-61779-767-5_3}}</ref>
[[File:Splice2.JPG|right|thumb|alt=Modified splice diagram for minigene splicing|pre-mRNA splice patterns showing constitutive exons and introns and the inserted fragment. Orange lines show alternative splicing outcomes as dictated by the exonic sequences and intronic sequences (yellow and green bands) that influence splicing. These sequences may be splicing enhancers or silencers, polypyrimidine tract binding protein sites or other elements.]]
==History==
Minigenes were first described as the somatic assembly of DNA segments and consisted of DNA regions known to encode the protein and the flanking regions required to express the protein. The term was first used in a paper in 1977 to describe the cloning of two minigenes that were designed to express a peptide.<ref name=Poonian>{{cite journal|last=Poonian|first=MS|last2=McComas|first2=WW|last3=Nussbaum|first3=AL|title=Chemical synthesis of two deoxyribododecanucleotides for the attachment of restriction termini to an artificial minigene|journal=Gene|year=1977|volume=1|issue=5–6|pages=357–72|pmid=590743|doi=10.1016/0378-1119(77)90040-3}}</ref>
RNA splicing was discovered in the late 1970s through the study of adenoviruses that invade mammals and replicate inside them. Researchers identified RNA molecules that contained sequences from noncontiguous parts of the virus’s genome. This discovery led to the conclusion that regulatory mechanisms existed which affected mature RNA and the genes it expresses.<ref name=Clancy>{{cite journal|last=Clancy|first=S|title=RNA splicing: introns, exons and spliceosome|journal=Nature Education|year=2008|volume=1|issue=31}}</ref> Using minigenes as a splice reporting vector to explore the effects of RNA splicing regulation naturally followed and remains the major use of minigenes to date.
==Types==
In order to provide a good minigene model, the gene fragment should have all of the necessary elements to ensure it exhibits the same [[Alternative splicing|alternative splicing (AS)]] patterns as the [[wild type]] gene, i.e., the length of the fragment must include all upstream and downstream sequences which can affect its splicing.<ref name=Stoss /><ref name=Cooper /> Therefore, most minigene designs begin with a thorough ''[[in silico]]'' analysis of the requirements of the experiment before any "wet" lab work is conducted.<ref name=Burge>{{cite web|last=Burge|first=Christopher|title=Burge Lab Software|url=http://genes.mit.edu/burgelab/software.html|accessdate=7 May 2014}}</ref> With the advent of [[Bioinformatics]] and widespread use of computers, several good programs now exist for the identification of cis-acting control regions that affect the splicing outcomes of a gene<ref name="Ab initio">{{cite journal|last=Divina|first=Petr|author2=Kvitkovicova, Andrea |author3=Buratti, Emanuele |author4= Vorechovsky, Igor |title=Ab initio prediction of mutation-induced cryptic splice-site activation and exon skipping|journal=European Journal of Human Genetics|date=14 January 2009|volume=17|issue=6|pages=759–765|doi=10.1038/ejhg.2008.257 |pmid=19142208 |pmc=2947103}}</ref><ref name=Grodecka>{{cite journal|last=Grodecká|first=Lucie|last2=Lockerová|first2= Pavla |last3=Ravčuková|first3= Barbora |last4=Buratti|first4= Emanuele |last5=Baralle|first5= Francisco E.|last6=Dušek|first6= Ladislav |last7=Freiberger|first7= Tomáš |last8= Spilianakis|first8= Charalampos Babis |title=Exon First Nucleotide Mutations in Splicing: Evaluation of In Silico Prediction Tools|journal=PLoS ONE|date=21 February 2014|volume=9|issue=2|pages=e89570|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0089570 |pmid=24586880 |pmc=3931810}}</ref> and advanced programs can even consider splicing outcomes in various tissue types.<ref name=AVISPA>{{cite journal|last=Barash|first=Yoseph|last2=Vaquero-Garcia|first2= Jorge |last3=González-Vallinas|first3= Juan |last4=Xiong|first4= Hui |last5=Gao|first5= Weijun |last6=Lee|first6= Leo J.|last7= Frey|first7= Brendan J.|title=AVISPA: a web tool for the prediction and analysis of alternative splicing|journal=Genome Biology|volume=14|issue=10|pages=R114|doi=10.1186/gb-2013-14-10-r114 |pmid=24156756 |pmc=4014802}}</ref> Differences in minigenes are usually reflected in the final size of the fragment, which is in turn a reflection of the complexity of the minigene itself. The number of foreign DNA elements (exon and introns) inserted into the constitutive exons and introns of a given fragment varies with the type of experiment and the information being sought. A typical experiment might involve [[wild type]] minigenes which are expected to express genes normally in a comparison run against genetically engineered [[Allele|allelic variations]] which replace the wild-type gene and have been cloned into the same flanking sequences as the original fragment. These types of experiments help to determine the effect of various mutations on [[pre-mRNA]] splicing.<ref name=Desviat />
==Construction==
Once a suitable genomic fragment is chosen (Step 1), the exons and introns of the fragment can be inserted and amplified, along with the flanking constitutive exons and introns of the original gene, by [[PCR]]. The primers for PCR can be chosen so that they leave "[[sticky ends]]" at 3' sense and anti-sense strands (Step 2). These "sticky-ends" can be easily incorporated into a TOPO Vector by ligation into a commercially available source which has ligase already attached to it at the sight of incorporation<ref>{{cite web|work=Life sciences|title=Steps in producing a TOPO Vector|url=http://www.lifetechnologies.com/us/en/home/life-science/cloning/topo/topo-resources/the-technology-behind-topo-cloning.html|accessdate=7 May 2014}}</ref> (Step 3). The subsequent TOPO Vectors can be transfected into E.coli cells (Step 4). After incubation, total RNA can be extracted from the bacterial colonies and analyzed using [[RT-PCR]] to quantify ratios of exon inclusion/exclusion (step 5). The minigene can be transfected into different cell types with various splicing factors to test trans-acting elements (Step 6). The expressed genes or the proteins they encode can be analyzed to evaluate splicing components and their effects via a variety of methods including [[Nucleic acid hybridisation#Hybridization|hybridization]] or [[size-exclusion chromatography]].<ref name=Stoss /><ref name=Cooper /> [[File:Minigen cycle1.JPG|right|thumb|upright 1.4| A typical cycle for constructing a minigene.]]
==Uses==
[[RNA splicing]] errors have been estimated to occur in a third of genetic diseases.{{Citation needed|date=September 2015}} To understand [[pathogenesis]] and identify potential targets of therapeutic intervention in these diseases, explicating the splicing elements involved is essential.<ref name=Kian>{{cite journal|last=Lim|first=Kian|author2=Huat |last3=Ferraris|first3= Luciana |last4=Filloux|first4= Madeleine E.|last5=Raphael|first5=Benjamin J.|last6= Fairbrother|first6= William G.|title=Using positional distribution to identify splicing elements and predict pre-mRNA processing defects in human genes|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|volume=108|issue=27|pages=11093–6|doi=10.1073/pnas.1101135108|pmid=21685335|accessdate=|pmc=3131313}}</ref> Determining the complete set of components involved in splicing presents many challenges due to the abundance of alternative splicing, which occurs in most human genes, and the specificity in which splicing is carried out ''in vivo''.<ref name=Cooper /> Splicing is distinctly conducted from cell type to cell type and across different stages of cellular development. Therefore, it is critical that any ''[[in vitro]]'' or bioinformatic assumptions about splicing regulation are confirmed ''in vivo''.<ref name=Stamm>{{cite web|last=Stamm|first=Stefan|title=Stamms-lab.net|url=http://www.stamms-lab.net/minigenes.htm|accessdate=26 March 2014}}</ref> Minigenes are used to elucidate ''cis''-regulatory elements, ''trans''-regulatory elements and other regulators of pre-mature RNA splicing ''in vivo''.<ref name=Cooper>{{cite journal|last=Cooper|first=Thomas A.|title=Use of minigene systems to dissect alternative splicing elements.|journal=Methods|date=December 2005|volume=37|issue=4|pages=331–340|doi=10.1016/j.ymeth.2005.07.015}}</ref> Minigenes have been applied to the study of a diverse array of genetic diseases due to the aforementioned abundance of alternatively spliced genes and the specificity and variation observed in splicing regulation.<ref name=Stoss>{{cite journal|last=Stoss|first=O|last2=Stoilov|first2=P|last3=Hartmann|first3=AM|last4=Nayler|first4=O|last5= Stamm|first5=S|title=The in vivo minigene approach to analyze tissue-specific splicing.|journal=Brain Research. Brain Research Protocols|date=Dec 1999|volume=4|issue=3|pages=383–94|pmid=10592349|doi=10.1016/s1385-299x(99)00043-4}}</ref><ref name=Cooper /><ref name=Stamm /> The following are examples of minigene use in various diseases. While it is not an exhaustive list, it does provide a better understanding of how minigenes are utilized.
===Endocrine diseases===
RNA splicing errors can have drastic effects on how proteins function, including the hormones secreted by the [[endocrine system]]. These effects on hormones have been identified as the cause of many endocrine disorders including thyroid-related pathological conditions, [[rickets]], [[hyperinsulinemic hypoglycemia]] and [[congenital adrenal hyperplasia]].<ref name="Miranda, Endocrine">{{cite journal|last=Rosaria de Miranda|first=Elizabete|title=Splicing variants impact in thyroid normal physiology and pathological conditions|journal=Arq Bras Endocrino Metab.|year=2009|volume=53|issue=6|pages=709–714|doi=10.1590/S0004-27302009000600003}}</ref> One specific example of a splicing error causing an endocrine disease that has been studied using minigenes is a type of [[growth hormone deficiency]] called isolated growth hormone deficiency (IGHD), a disease that results in growth failure. IGHD type II is an autosomal dominant form caused by a mutation in the intervening sequence (IVS) adjacent to exon 3 of the gene encoding growth hormone 1, the GH-1 gene. This mutated form of IVS3 causes exon 3 to be skipped in the mRNA product. The mRNA (-E3) encodes a truncated form of hGH that then inhibits normal hGH secretion. Minigenes were used to determine that a [[point mutation]] within an intron splice enhancer (ISE) embedded in IVS3 was to blame for the skipping of E3. Moreover, it was determined that the function of the ISE is influenced by a nearby [[Ac/Ds Activator/Dissociation Transposable Element|transposable AC element]], revealing that this particular splicing error is caused by a trans-acting factor.<ref name="Mullis - Endocrine">{{cite journal|last=Mullis|first=PE|title=Genetics of isolated growth hormone deficiency.|journal=J Clin Res Pediatr Endocrinol|year=2010|volume=2|issue=2|pages=52–62|doi=10.4274/jcrpe.v2i2.52|pmc=3014602}}</ref>
===Neurodegenerative diseases===
Accumulation of [[tau protein]] is associated with [[Neurodegeneration|neurodegenerative diseases]] including [[Alzheimer's disease|Alzheimer's]] and [[Parkinson's disease|Parkinson's]] diseases as well as other [[Tauopathy|tauopathies]].<ref name="Kar, Neuro">{{cite journal|last=Kar|first=Amar|first2= Kazuo |last2=Fushimi|first3= Xiaohong|last3= Zhou|first4= Payal |last4=Ray|first5= Chen |last5=Shi|first6= Xiaoping|last6= Chen|first7= Zhiren |last7=Liu|first8= She |last8=Chen|first9= Jane Y.|last9= Wu|title=RNA Helicase p68 (DDX5) Regulates tau Exon 10 Splicing by Modulating a Stem-Loop Structure at the 5′ Splice Site|journal=Mol. Cell. Biol.|year=2011|volume=31|issue=9|pages=1812–1821|doi=10.1128/MCB.01149-10|pmc=3133221}}</ref> Tau protein isoforms are created by alternative splicing of exons 2, 3 and 10. The regulation of tau splicing is specific to stage of development, physiology and location. Errors in tau splicing can occur in both exons and introns and, depending on the error, result in changes to protein structure or loss of function.<ref name="Rodriguez-Martin, Neuro">{{cite journal|last=Rodriguez-Martin|first=Teresa|author2=Karen Anthony|author3= Mariano A. Garcia-Blanco|author4= S. Gary Mansfield|author5= Brian H. Anderton|author6= Jean-Marc Gallo|title=Correction of tau mis-splicing caused by FTDP-17 MAPT mutations by spliceosome-mediated RNA trans-splicing|journal=Hum Mol Genet|year=2009|volume=18|issue=17|pages=3266–3273|doi=10.1093/hmg/ddp264|pmc=2722988}}</ref> Aggregation of these abnormal tau proteins correlates directly with pathogenesis and disease progression. Minigenes have been used by several researchers to help understand the regulatory components responsible for mRNA splicing of the TAU gene.<ref name="Kar, Neuro" /><ref name="Rodriguez-Martin, Neuro" /><ref name="Anfossi - Neuro">{{cite journal|last=Anfossi|first=M|last2=Vuono|first2=R|last3= Maletta|first3=R|last4= Virdee|first4=K|last5= Mirabelli|first5=M|last6= Colao|first6=R|last7= Puccio|first7=G|last8= Bernardi|first8=L|last9= Frangipane|first9=F|last10= Gallo|first10=M|last11= Geracitano|first11=S|last12= Tomaino|first12=C|last13= Curcio|first13=SA|last14= Zannino|first14=G|last15= Lamenza|first15=F|last16= Duyckaerts|first16=C|last17= Spillantini|first17=MG|last18= Losso|first18=MA|last19= Bruni|first19=AC|title=Compound heterozygosity of 2 novel MAPT mutations in frontotemporal dementia|journal=Neurobiol Aging|year=2011|volume=32|issue=4|doi=10.1016/j.neurobiolaging.2010.12.013|pages=757.e1–757.e11}}</ref>
===Cancer=== Cancer is a complex, heterogeneous disease that can be hereditary or the result of environmental stimuli.<ref name="Rajan Cancer">{{cite journal|last=Rajan|first=P.|last2=Elliott|first2=DJ|last3=Robson|first3=CN|last4=Leung|first4=HY|title=Alternative splicing and biological heterogeneity in prostate cancer.|journal=Nat Rev Urol |date=Aug 2009 |pages=454–460 |volume=6|issue=8|doi=10.1038/nrurol.2009.125}}</ref> Minigenes are used to help oncologists understand the roles [[Precursor mRNA|pre-mRNA]] splicing plays in different cancer types. Of particular interest are cancer specific genetic mutations that disrupt normal splicing events, including those affecting [[spliceosome]] components and [[RNA-binding protein]]s such as [[Heterogeneous ribonucleoprotein particle|heterogeneous nuclear ribonucleoparticules (hnRNP)]], [[SR protein|serine/arginine-rich (SR) proteins]] and [[snRNP|small ribonucleoproteins (snRNP)]].<ref name="Adler - cancer">{{cite journal|last=Adler|first=AS|last2=McCleland|first2=ML|last3=Yee|first3=S|last4=Yaylaoglu|first4=M|last5=Hussain|first5=S|last6=Cosino|first6=E|last7=Quinones|first7=G|last8=Modrusan|first8=Z|last9=Seshagiri|first9=S|last10=Torres|first10=E|last11=Chopra|first11=VS|last12=Haley|first12=B|last13=Zhang|first13=Z|last14=Blackwood|first14=EM|last15=Singh|first15=M|last16=Junttila|first16=M|last17=Stephan|first17=JP|last18=Liu|first18=J|last19=Pau|first19=G|last20=Fearon|first20=ER|last21=Jiang|first21=Z|last22=Firestein|first22=R|title=An integrative analysis of colon cancer identifies an essential function for PRPF6 in tumor growth|journal=Genes Dev.|date=May 2014|pmid=24788092|doi=10.1101/gad.237206.113|volume=28|issue=10|pages=1068–84|pmc=4035536}}</ref><ref name="Guo - Cancer">{{cite journal|last=Guo|first=Rong|author2=Yong Li |author3=Jinying Ning |author4=Dan Sun |author5=Lianjun Lin |author6=Xinmin Liu |title=HnRNP A1/A2 and SF2/ASF Regulate Alternative Splicing of Interferon Regulatory Factor-3 and Affect Immunomodulatory Functions in Human Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer Cells|journal=PLoS ONE|year=2013|volume=8|issue=4|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0062729 |pages=e62729 |pmid=23658645 |pmc=3639176}}</ref> Proteins encoded by aberrantly spliced pre-mRNAs are functionally different and contribute to the characteristic anomalies exhibited by cancer cells, including their ability to proliferate, invade and undergo angiogenesis, and metastasis.<ref name="Guo - Cancer" /> Minigenes help researchers identify genetic mutations in cancer that result in splicing errors and determine the downstream effects those splicing errors have on gene expression.<ref name="Acedo breast cancer">{{cite journal|last=Acedo|first=Alberto |author2=David J Sanz |author3=Mercedes Durán |author4=Mar Infante |author5=Lucía Pérez-Cabornero |author6=Cristina Miner |author7=Eladio A Velasco|title=Comprehensive splicing functional analysis of DNA variants of the BRCA2 gene by hybrid minigenes|journal=Breast Cancer Research|year=2012|volume=14|issue=3|doi=10.1186/bcr3202 |pages=R87}}</ref> Using knowledge obtained from studies employing minigenes, oncologists have proposed tests designed to detect products of abnormal gene expression for diagnostic purposes.<ref name="Di Giacomo - Cancer">{{cite journal|last=Di Giacomo|first=D.|last2=Gaildrat|first2=P|last3=Abuli|first3=A|last4=Abdat|first4=J|last5=Frébourg|first5=T|last6=Tosi|first6=M|last7=Martins|first7=A|title=Functional analysis of a large set of BRCA2 exon 7 variants highlights the predictive value of hexamer scores in detecting alterations of exonic splicing regulatory elements|journal=Hum. Mutat.|year=2013|volume=34|issue=11|pages=1547–57|doi=10.1002/humu.22428}}</ref> Additionally, the prospect of using minigenes as a [[cancer immunotherapy]] is being explored.<ref name="Daniotti cancer vacc">{{cite journal|last=Daniotti|first=Jose L.|author2=Aldo A. Vilcaes |author3=Vanina Torres Demichelis |author4=Fernando M. Ruggiero |author5=Macarena Rodriguez-Walker |title=Glycosylation of Glycolipids in Cancer: Basis for Development of Novel Therapeutic Approaches|journal=Front Oncol|year=2013|volume=3|issue=|doi=10.3389/fonc.2013.00306|pmc=3867695 |pages=306 |pmid=24392350}}</ref><ref name="Aurisicchio - Cancer">{{cite journal|last=Aurisicchio|first=L|last2=Fridman|first2=A|last3=Bagchi|first3=A|last4=Scarselli|first4=E|last5=La Monica|first5=N|last6=Ciliberto|first6=G|title=A novel minigene scaffold for therapeutic cancer vaccines|journal=Oncoimmunology|date=Jan 2014|volume=3|issue=1|pmid=24790791|doi=10.4161/onci.27529|pages=e27529}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Recombinant DNA]] * [[RNA splicing|RNA Splicing]] * [[Exon]] * [[Intron]] * [[Transfection]] * [[Cloning vector]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==Further reading==
* "Alternative pre-mRNA Splicing: Theory and Protocols", by Stefan Stamm, Chris Smith and Reinhard Lührmann {{ISBN|978-3527326068}} * "Molecular Diagnostics, Second edition", by Ed. by George P. Patrinos and Whilhelm Ansorge {{ISBN|0123745373}} * "DNA Vaccines" edited by Hildegun Ertl {{ISBN|1461349257}} * "Alternative Splicing and Disease (Progress in Molecular and Subcellular Biology)" by Philippe Jeanteur {{ISBN|3540344489}}
==External links== * [http://www.stamms-lab.net/minigenes.htm Stefan Stamm's web page at the University of Kentucky]. Good overview of minigene research. * [http://genes.mit.edu/burgelab/software.html Christopher Burge's Lab at M.I.T. website]. A Good site for theoretical analysis of splicing. * [http://genome.ucsc.edu/ UCSC Genome Browser]. Large database for retrieving information on genes.

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2017}} {{Infobox ice hockey player | name = Miro Aaltonen | image = Miro Aaltonen.jpg | image_size = 225px | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1993|6|7}} | birth_place = [[Joensuu]], Finland | height_ft = 6 | height_in = 0 | weight_lb = 176 | position = [[Centre (ice hockey)|Centre]] | shoots = Left | league = [[Kontinental Hockey League|KHL]] | team = [[HC Vityaz]] | prospect_team = | prospect_league = | former_teams = [[Espoo Blues]]
[[Oulun Kärpät|Kärpät]]
[[Toronto Marlies]] | ntl_team = FIN | draft = 177th overall | draft_year = 2013 | draft_team = [[Anaheim Ducks]] | career_start = 2011 | career_end = }} '''Miro Aaltonen''' (born 7 June 1993) is a [[Finland|Finnish]] professional [[ice hockey]] [[Forward (ice hockey)|forward]]. He is currently playing with [[HC Vityaz]] of the [[Kontinental Hockey League]] (KHL).{{citeweb| url = http://www.sportsnet.ca/hockey/nhl/maple-leafs-sign-khl-forward-miro-aaltonen-entry-level-contract/ | title = Miro Aaltonen signing with Toronto Maple Leafs | publisher = ''[[Sportsnet.ca]]'' | date = 2017-03-17 | accessdate = 2017-03-17}} Aaltonen was selected by [[Atlant Moscow Oblast]] in the 2nd round (45th overall) of the [[2011 KHL Junior Draft]], and he was also selected by the [[Anaheim Ducks]] in the 6th round (177th overall) of the [[2013 NHL Entry Draft]]. ==Playing career== Following the [[2016-17 KHL season|2016–17]] season, after recording a career best 44 points in 59 games after his first season with [[HC Vityaz]] in the [[Kontinental Hockey League]], he signed an entry-level contract with the [[Toronto Maple Leafs]] on March 17, 2017. Despite a strong push for a roster spot as the Leafs' [[Line (ice hockey)|fourth-line]] center, he was assigned to the Maple Leafs [[American Hockey League]] affiliate, the [[Toronto Marlies]] for the [[2017–18 AHL season|2017–18]] season. In adapting to his first North American season, Aaltonen established himself among the offensive leaders with the Marlies, contributing with 20 goals and 43 points in 64 regular season games. Unable to earn a call up to the NHL, Aaltonen continued in the post-season with the Marlies, helping claim the club's first [[Calder Cup]] in posting 13 points in 20 games. As an impending restricted free agent from the Maple Leafs but unable to make his NHL debut, Aaltonen opted to return to the KHL on a contract with former Russian club, Vityaz on July 1, 2018.{{Citeweb| url = http://www.hcvityaz.ru/news.php?full=9650 | title = Miro Aaltonen returns to Vityaz | publisher = ''[[HC Vityaz]]'' | date = 2018-07-01 | accessdate = 2018-07-01 | language = Russia}} ==Career statistics== ===Regular season and playoffs=== {| border="0" cellpadding="1" cellspacing="0" style="text-align:center; width:60em;" |- style="background:#e0e0e0;" ! colspan="3" bgcolor="#ffffff" |   ! rowspan="100" bgcolor="#ffffff" |   ! colspan="5" | [[regular season|Regular season]] ! rowspan="100" bgcolor="#ffffff" |   ! colspan="5" | [[Playoffs]] |- style="background:#e0e0e0;" ! {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2015}} {{Infobox military person | honorific_prefix = | name = Muath al-Kasasbeh | honorific_suffix = | image = Muath AlKesasbeh.jpg{{!}}border | image_size = | alt = | caption = | native_name = معاذ صافي يوسف الكساسبة | native_name_lang = ar | birth_name = Muath Safi Yousef al-Kasasbeh | nickname = | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1988|05|29}} |death_date = c. {{Death date and age|df=yes|2015|1|3|1988|5|29}} | birth_place = [[Al Karak|Karak]], [[Jordan]] | death_place = [[Raqqa]], [[Syria]] | placeofburial = Syria | placeofburial_label= | placeofburial_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|display=inline,title}} --> | allegiance = {{flag|Jordan|size=23px}} | branch = {{Flagicon image|Air Force Ensign of Jordan.svg|size=23px}} [[Royal Jordanian Air Force]] | serviceyears = 2009–15 | rank = [[Jordanian military ranks|1st lieutenant]] (promoted posthumously to captain) | servicenumber = <!-- Do not use data from primary sources such as service records --> | unit = No. 1 Squadron | commands = | battles = [[Military intervention against ISIL]] | battles_label = | awards = | memorials = | spouse = Anwar al-Tarawneh | relations = | religion = [[Sunni Islam]] | laterwork = }} '''Muath Safi Yousef al-Kasasbeh''' ({{lang-ar|معاذ صافي يوسف الكساسبة}}  <small>[[South Levantine Arabic|South Levantine]] pronunciation:</small> {{IPA-ar|mʊˈʕaːð-, mʊˈʕaːz ˈsˤɑːfi ˈjuːsef el kaˈsaːsbe|}}; 29 May 1988<ref>{{cite news| author =Heather Saul and Kashmira Gander| title =Isis 'did not shoot down Jordan war plane' before capturing pilot, says US| quote =RMC later posted a photograph of the Jordanian military identity card of the pilot identifying him as Mu'ath Safi Yousef al-Kaseasbeh who was born on May 29, 1988.| newspaper =[[The Independent]]| date = 24 December 2014| url =https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/isis-fighters-shoot-down-usled-coalition-war-plane-and-capture-jordanian-pilot-9944068.html| accessdate =3 January 2015}}</ref> – c. 3 January 2015)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/feb/03/isis-video-jordanian-hostage-burdning-death-muadh-al-kasabeh|title=Isis video shows Jordanian hostage being burned to death|author=Shiv Malik|date=4 February 2015|accessdate=17 February 2015|work=The Guardian|location=United Kingdom}}</ref> was a [[Royal Jordanian Air Force]] pilot who was captured and burned to death by the militant terrorist group [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|ISIL]] after his [[Lockheed Martin F-16|F-16]] fighter aircraft crashed over [[Syria]].
His fighter crashed near [[Raqqa]], Syria, on 24 December 2014 during the [[Military intervention against ISIL|military intervention against the Islamic State]]. United States and Jordanian officials said that the crash was caused by mechanical problems, while ISIL claimed that the plane was hit by a heat-seeking missile.<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-31021927|title= Profile: IS-held Jordanian pilot Moaz al-Kasasbeh|work=BBC News}}</ref><ref name=YT20141226 />
ISIL held al-Kasasbeh captive before killing him in early January 2015. It then conducted negotiations with the Jordanian government, claiming it would spare al-Kasabeh's life and free Japanese journalist [[Kenji Goto]] in exchange for [[Sajida Mubarak Atrous al-Rishawi|Sajida al-Rishawi]], a woman sentenced to death by Jordan for attempted terrorism and possessing explosives.<ref name="auto3">{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/family-jordanian-pilot-held-islamic-state-demands-word-071810825.html|title=Jordan committed to anti-IS coalition, despite hostage drama|date=1 February 2015|work=Yahoo News}}</ref> After the Jordanian government insisted on freeing al-Kasasbeh as part of the deal and showing proof that he was alive before it would exchange al-Rishawi, ISIS released a video on 3 February 2015 showing al-Kasasbeh being burned to death while trapped inside a cage.
Al-Kasasbeh's killing provoked widespread outrage in Jordan, and condemnation by leading figures of the Islamic world and subsequently led the Jordanian government to execute two Iraqi militants on death row in retaliation over the killing. In retaliation, [[Abdullah II of Jordan|King Abdullah]] ordered [[Operation Martyr Muath]], a series of airstrikes that killed a number of ISIL militants over the course of three days.
==Personal life== Al-Kasasbeh was one of eight children, including an elder brother, Jawdat Safi al-Kasasbeh, born to Issaf and Safi Yousef al-Kasasbeh, a retired education professor, in [[Al Karak]], Jordan.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2015/02/04/egypt-reviles-isis-killing-jordanian-pilot-al-kasasbeh/|title=Egypt reviles ISIS killing of Jordanian pilot Al-Kasasbeh – Daily News Egypt|work=Daily News Egypt}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| author =Rod Nordland and Ranya Kadri| title =Jordan Executes Prisoners After ISIS Video of Pilot's Death| quote =| newspaper =[[The New York Times]]| date =3 February 2015| url =https://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/04/world/middleeast/isis-said-to-burn-captive-jordanian-pilot-to-death-in-new-video.html| accessdate =4 February 2014}}</ref><ref name="alarabiya1">{{cite web|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2015/02/04/Profile-of-Jordan-s-patriotic-pilot.html|title=Profile of a patriotic pilot: Moaz al-Kasasbeh|publisher=Al Arabiya News|date=4 February 2015}}</ref> He was a [[Sunni Islam|Sunni Muslim]].<ref>{{cite news| author =| title =Profile: IS-held Jordanian pilot Moaz al-Kasasbeh| quote =Lt Kasasbeh's family urged IS to spare him, stressing that he was a devout Sunni Muslim.| newspaper =[[BBC News]]| date = 3 February 2015| url =https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-31021927| accessdate =3 February 2015}}</ref> The Al-Kasasbehs are a prominent Jordanian family of the influential Sunni Muslim Bararsheh tribe from southern Jordan.<ref name="sky.com1">{{cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/story/1418945/is-hostage-pilots-brother-its-not-our-war|title=IS Hostage Pilot's Brother: 'It's Not Our War'|work=Sky News}}</ref> His uncle, Fahed al-Kasasbeh, was a [[Major General]] in the [[Royal Jordanian Army]].<ref name="nytimes.com1">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/01/world/middleeast/tribes-at-center-of-effort-to-free-jordanian-pilot.html|title=Tribal Loyalties Drive Jordan’s Effort to Free Pilot |date=1 February 2015|work=The New York Times|accessdate=20 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/world/jordan-warns-islamic-state-militants-against-harming-captured-pilot-20141226-12dstm.html?skin=text-only |title=Jordan warns Islamic State militants against harming captured pilot |publisher=www.smh.com.au |date=26 December 2014 |accessdate=6 February 2015}}</ref>
Al-Kasasbeh married engineer Anwar al-Tarawneh in September 2014.<ref>{{cite news| author =Mitchell Prothero| title =Jordan prepares to execute ISIS prisoners as retaliation for savage killing| quote =Anwar al-Tarawneh, the wife of Jordanian pilot, Lt. Moaz Al-Kasasbeh, who was burned to death by Islamic State group militants, holds a poster of him as she weeps during a protest in Amman, Jordan, Tuesday, Feb. 3, 2015.| newspaper =[[The McClatchy Company|McClatchy Foreign]] via [[The Telegraph (Macon)|The Telegraph]]| date =3 February 2015| url =http://www.macon.com/2015/02/03/3565963/islamic-state-video-said-to-show.html| accessdate =3 February 2015}}</ref> Prior to his capture, al-Kasasbeh lived in the village of Ay in the Karak Mountains in [[Karak Governorate]], {{convert|90|mi|km}} south of [[Amman]].<ref name="sky.com1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2015/02/05/world/isis-jordan/|title=Jordan unleashes wrath on ISIS: 'This is just the beginning'|author=Greg Botelho and Jomana Karadsheh|date=5 February 2015|work=CNN}}</ref>
== Career ==
In 2009, al-Kasasbeh graduated from the [[King Hussein Air College]] and joined the [[Royal Jordanian Air Force]]. He completed his F-16 training in The Royal Jordanian Air Force, By 2012 he qualified as an operational F-16 pilot and was assigned to No. 1 Squadron at [[Muwaffaq Salti Air Base]].<ref name="alarabiya1"/>
At the time of his capture, al-Kasasbeh was a [[First Lieutenant]].<ref name="nytimes.com1"/> He was posthumously promoted to the rank of Captain.
==Capture== [[File:Two F-16 of the Royal Jordanian Air Force.jpg|thumb|left|Jordanian F-16s, similar to those operated by Al-Kasasbeh, in October 2009]] The plane al-Kasasbeh was piloting, a [[Lockheed Martin F-16]] formerly used by the [[Royal Belgian Air Force]], crashed after suffering from mechanical problems on 24 December 2014 during a bombing raid on a brick factory during the military intervention against the Islamic State.<ref name=YT20141226>{{cite web|title=Jordan pilot ejected over Syria after 'technical failure'|url=https://news.yahoo.com/jordan-denies-jihadists-shot-down-warplane-131419028.html|website=Yahoo News|publisher=Yahoo|accessdate=26 December 2014}}</ref> The Jordanian government said a technical failure caused him to eject after flying at low altitude, but the Islamic State claimed it shot down his aircraft.<ref name=YT20141226 /><ref name="auto2">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-31021927|title=Profile: IS-held Jordanian pilot Moaz al-Kasasbeh|work=BBC News}}</ref> He ejected and parachuted into a lake near [[Raqqa|Raqqa, Syria]]. He was quickly captured by Islamic State militants and pulled from the water.<ref name="nytimes.com1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2015/01/29/middleeast/who-is-jordan-pilot-isis-hostage/|title=Who was Jordanian pilot Moath al-Kasasbeh, killed by ISIS?|author=Laura Smith-Spark and Michael Martinez|date=29 January 2015|work=CNN}}</ref><ref name="arabnews.com1">{{cite web|url=http://www.arabnews.com/featured/news/700446|title=US moves pilot-rescue teams closer as Coalition steps up war against IS|work=arabnews.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/world/isis-terrorists-shoot-jordanian-plane-capture-pilot-article-1.2055578|title=ISIS terrorists capture Jordan pilot, plane not shot down|work=NY Daily News}}</ref> US officials state they initiated a search and rescue mission, but they did not locate him before he was captured.<ref name="arabnews.com1"/> On 30 December 2014, al-Kasasbeh appeared in a detailed interview with ISIS's [[Dabiq (magazine)|Dabiq]] magazine.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2015/02/04/Profile-of-Jordan-s-patriotic-pilot.html|title=Profile of a patriotic pilot: Moaz al-Kasasbeh|website=english.alarabiya.net|language=en|access-date=2018-04-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/isis-terror/when-did-jordan-find-out-hostage-pilot-muath-al-kasasbeh-n299896|title=When Did Jordan Find Out Hostage Pilot Muath al-Kasasbeh Was Dead?|author=Cassandra Vinograd|work=NBC News|accessdate=20 January 2016}}</ref>
Unsuccessful negotiations took place for his release. His family applied pressure on the Jordanian government to arrange for his release. Originally, it was proposed to trade him and a kidnapped Japanese journalist, [[Kenji Goto]], for [[Sajida Mubarak Atrous al-Rishawi|Sajida al-Rishawi]], a failed Iraqi [[suicide bomber]] incarcerated in Jordan since she took part in the [[2005 Amman bombings|2005 Amman hotel bombings]], and sentenced to death.<ref name="auto4">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-31121160|title= Jordan pilot hostage Moaz al-Kasasbeh 'burned alive'|work=BBC News}}</ref> The Jordanian government insisted on proof that al-Kasasbeh was still alive before it could proceed with a swap. The Islamic State refused and published the video of his killing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jordantimes.com/jordan-confirms-death-of-pilot-says-killed-january-3 |title=Jordan confirms death of pilot, says killed January 3 |publisher=The Jordan Times |date=27 January 2015 |accessdate=3 February 2015}}</ref> Some analysts have assessed IS's offer of prisoner exchange as a gimmick that was meant to put into disrepute or mock the commitment of the Jordanian government to the military intervention against it. There have also been suggestions that the proposal was a tactic intended to free its valued member in exchange for a corpse.{{citation needed|date=February 2015}}
A military operation to free al-Kasasbeh, possibly by [[Joint Special Operations Command (Jordan)|Jordanian special forces]], may have been made on 1 January 2015. Members of an anti-IS group in Raqqa, named [[Raqqa Is Being Slaughtered Silently]], said they witnessed coalition jets bombing targets in Raqqa in some of the fiercest strikes of the anti-IS campaign, while four helicopters dropped off soldiers wearing purported Jordanian Army uniforms. The mission was aborted when IS fighters in the area began firing anti-aircraft missiles at the helicopters, forcing a retreat.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/special-forces-may-have-tried-rescue-jordanian-pilot-muath-al-kasaesbeh-1805416|title=Special Forces May Have Tried To Rescue Jordanian Pilot Muath al-Kasaesbeh|date=4 February 2015|work=International Business Times}}</ref>
==Death== ISIS supporters used the Arabic hashtag #SuggestAWayToKillTheJordanianPilotPig on Twitter, crowdsourcing and publicizing their execution of al-Kasasbeh.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2939196/Was-Jordanian-pilot-burned-alive-sick-Twitter-campaign-ISIS-supporters-method-death.html|title=Was Jordanian pilot burned alive after sick Twitter campaign among ISIS supporters to name his method of death?|publisher=dailymail}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/news/isis-polls-twitter-for-gruesome-suggestions-of-how-to-kill-jordanian-pilot-9949550.html|title=Isis militants 'using Twitter to ask for suggestions on how to kill Jordanian pilot'|publisher=independent}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.haaretz.com/middle-east-news/1.640631|title=ISIS Video Shows Captured Jordanian Pilot Being Burned Alive|publisher=haaretz}}</ref> A film released by the group showed al-Kasasbeh was [[Death by burning|burned to death]] by [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|ISIS]] members in January 2015.<ref name="auto3"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/02/01/us-mideast-crisis-jordan-dilemma-idUSKBN0L51OZ20150201|title=Pilot held by Islamic State puts Jordan's king in a tough spot|work=Reuters}}</ref> His killing was recorded on video and shown near the end of a 22-minute "[[snuff film]]" entitled ''Healing the Believers' Chests'', credited to the ISIS official [[Al Furqan Media Foundation]] and distributed via a Twitter account known as a source for IS propaganda, and on video-sharing sites.<ref name="auto4"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2015/02/jordan-pilot-ISIS-execution-unity-Mouath-al-Kasaesbeh-King-Abdullah-revenge/385147/|title=Jordan's King Abdullah Vows Revenge for Death of Mouath al-Kasaesbeh, Who Was Burned Alive by ISIS |work=The Atlantic|author=Adam Chandler|date=4 February 2015}}</ref><ref name="aol.com1">{{cite web|url=http://www.aol.com/article/2015/02/03/video-claims-to-show-isis-terrorists-burning-pilot-alive/21138558/|title=Video claims to show ISIS terrorists burning pilot alive|work=AOL.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://nieuws.thepostonline.nl/2015/02/03/isis-verbrandt-gevangengenomen-jordaanse-piloot-levend/|title=Video: IS verbrandt gevangengenomen Jordaanse piloot levend|publisher=The Post Online|date=3 February 2015}} (in Dutch; includes a [http://www.dumpert.nl/embed/6638265/30337e4b/ excerpt] of the immolation via LiveLeak as an inline illustration)</ref>
The video shows him with a [[Black eye|black left eye]], first at a table and then confined in a black steel cage outdoors and dressed in an orange jumpsuit before an ISIL militant sets alight a trail doused in [[gasoline]]<nowiki/> leading towards the cage. He was burned alive while numerous armed ISIL fighters in sand-colored [[Balaclava (clothing)|balaclava]]s and desert-style camouflage watched on from a distance. A truck finally extinguishes the fire by dumping rocks and sand on it.<ref name="aol.com1"/>
Before he was burned to death, al-Kasasbeh was made to reveal the names and workplaces of a number of his fellow Royal Jordanian Air Force pilots.<ref name="aol.com2">{{cite web|url=http://www.aol.com/article/2015/02/03/video-claims-to-show-isis-terrorists-burning-pilot-alive/21138558/|title=Video claims to show ISIS terrorists burning pilot alive - AOL.com|work=AOL Article}}</ref><ref name="martinchulov">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/feb/04/jordan-executes-female-would-be-suicide-bomber-wanted-for-release-by-isis|title=Jordan executes would-be suicide bomber wanted for release by Islamic State|author=Martin Chulov|work=the Guardian}}</ref> Their names and photographs were displayed at the end of the video, with an ISIS bounty offer of 100 [[Modern gold dinar#Islamic State|gold dinar]]s (approximately $20,000) for each Jordanian Air Force pilot killed.<ref name="aol.com2"/><ref name="martinchulov"/>
Most Western media outlets refused to show the full video, sometimes describing it or showing images immediately preceding al-Kasasbeh's immolation.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/erik-wemple/wp/2015/02/03/islamic-state-burning-video-news-organizations-describe-it-dont-show-it/|title=Islamic State burning video: News organizations describe it, don't show it|publisher=Washington Post|date=3 February 2015|author=Erik Wemple}}</ref> [[Fox News]] posted the complete video on its website.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2015/02/04/new-isis-video-purpotedly-shows-jordanian-pilot-being-burned-alive.html|title=Jordan executes 2 prisoners after ISIS video shows pilot being burned alive|publisher=Fox News|date=2015-02-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2015/feb/04/fox-news-shows-isis-video-jordan-pilot/|title=Fox News website embeds unedited Isis video showing brutal murder of Jordanian pilot|publisher=The Guardian|date=4 February 2015|author=Nicky Woolf}}</ref>
The Jordanian government assessed that al-Kasasbeh was killed [[Death by burning|by burning]] on 3 January, rather than 3 February, when the video was released on Twitter. This confirmed that the ISIS never intended to exchange him for al-Rishawi. Other news reports suggest that he may have been killed a few days later, on 8 January, according to a tweet posted by a Syrian activist from Raqqa that day claiming he saw individuals from ISIS celebrating the death of al-Kasasbeh on 8 January.<ref name=Burnews1 /> It was reported that al-Kasasbeh was deprived of food beginning five days before he was killed.<ref name=Burnews1>{{cite web|url=http://www.burnews.com/%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B7%D9%8A%D8%A7%D8%B1-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A3%D8%B1%D8%AF%D9%86%D9%8A-%D8%AD%D9%8F%D8%B1%D9%85-%D9%85%D9%86-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B7%D8%B9%D8%A7%D9%85-%D9%82%D8%A8%D9%84-%D8%A5%D8%B9%D8%AF%D8%A7%D9%85%D9%87-%D8%A8%D8%AE%D9%85%D8%B3%D8%A9-%D8%A3%D9%8A%D8%A7%D9%85/%D9%85%D8%AF%D8%A7%D8%B1%D8%A7%D8%AA-%D8%B9%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D9%8A%D8%A9|title=الطيار الأردني حُرم من الطعام قبل إعدامه بخمسة أيام|work=صحيفة عاجل الإلكترونية}}</ref>
On 25 February 2015, al-l'tisam, a media arm of ISIS, released a video entitled ''Message to Jordan''. It showed new excerpts from the video of al-Kasasbeh's burning.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jihadology.net/2015/02/25/al-iti%E1%B9%A3am-media-presents-a-new-video-message-from-the-islamic-state-message-to-jordan/|title=al-I'tiṣām Media presents a new video message from The Islamic State: "Message to Jordan" - JIHADOLOGY: A clearinghouse for jihādī primary source material, original analysis, and translation service|work=JIHADOLOGY: A clearinghouse for jihādī primary source material, original analysis, and translation service|accessdate=20 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://stepagency-sy.net/archives/36071|title=بالفيديو : تنظيم الدولة يوجه " رسالة الى الاردن " ويبث لقطات جديدة لعملية احراق الطيار الاردني " معاذ الكساسبة " - وكالة خطوة الإخبارية|work=وكالة خطوة الإخبارية|accessdate=20 January 2016}}</ref>
According to a former ISIS militant, senior ISIS leader [[Abu Mohammed al-Adnani]] personally burned al-Kasasbeh alive.<ref>http://english.alarabiya.net/en/media/television-and-radio/2017/02/11/Former-ISIS-militant-reveals-details-on-filming-of-Jordanian-pilot-s-execution.html</ref><ref>https://www.memri.org/tv/people-behind-isis-media-system-speak-al-arabiya-tv-documentary/transcript</ref>
==Reaction== [[File:Moath Kasasbeh memorial - Jordan University 03.JPG|thumb|right|Muath al-Kasasbeh's memorial at the [[University of Jordan]].]] Al-Kasasbeh's killing provoked outrage in Jordan; even some of those who had been opposed to the country's participation in airstrikes against IS started demanding revenge.<ref name=ChulovGuardian>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/feb/04/isis-muadh-al-kasasbeh-death-jordan-revenge-mood|title=Jordanians turn their minds to revenge after Isis killing of pilot|author=Martin Chulov|work=The Guardian}}</ref>
King [[Abdullah II of Jordan|Abdullah II]] cut short a visit to the United States, and the Jordanian government announced that all prisoners in its custody who had been convicted of association with IS would be executed "within hours" in retaliation for Al-Kasasbeh's killing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2938199/Burned-alive-cage-ISIS-release-video-claiming-horrifying-murder-captured-Jordanian-pilot.html|title=Jordan announces execution of six ISIS prisoners 'within hours' in retaliation after terrorists release lavish video of Jordanian pilot being TORCHED to death in a cage in yet another new low for humanity|publisher=Daily Mail|date=3 February 2015|author=John Hall and Tom Wyke and Steph Cockroft for MailOnline and David Williams, Chief Reporter for the Daily Mail}}</ref> In further response, Mamdouh al-Ameri, a [[Jordanian Armed Forces|Jordanian military]] spokesman, said: "While the military forces mourn the martyr, they emphasize his blood will not be shed in vain. The revenge will be as big as the calamity that has hit Jordan."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsweek.com/isis-execution-jordan-pilot-302659|title=Report: ISIS Executes Jordanian Pilot|author=|date=3 February 2015|work=Newsweek}}</ref>
On 4 February 2015, al-Rishawi and another Iraqi jihadist who was also on death row, [[Ziad Khalaf Raja al-Karbouly|Ziad Khalaf al-Karbouly]], were executed by [[hanging]] in Swaqa Prison, expedited in response to Al-Kasasbeh's death.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Michaels|first1=Jim|last2=Bacon|first2=John|title=Jordan executes two in response to pilot's slaying|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2015/02/03/islamic-state-jordanian-pilot/22798055/|accessdate=4 February 2015|agency=USA Today}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Jordan executes Sajida al-Rishawi after pilot murder |newspaper=[[Al Arabiya|Al Arabiya News English]] |date=4 February 2015 |url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2015/02/04/Jordan-to-execute-jailed-would-be-bomber-jihadists-security.html |accessdate=3 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://old.mehrnews.com/ar/NewsDetail.aspx?NewsID=1849387|title=Jordan executes two terrorists after alkasasabeh murder|work=MehrNews|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150205120154/http://old.mehrnews.com/ar/NewsDetail.aspx?NewsID=1849387|archivedate=5 February 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Later on 4 February, Jordan launched its first military response to al-Kasasbeh's killing. Jordanian warplanes bombed IS positions in [[Mosul]], killing 55 IS fighters, including a senior commander.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.i24news.tv/en/news/international/middle-east/60008-150204-king-abdullah-lands-in-jordan-following-murder-of-pilot|title=Jordan carries out air strikes in Iraq, killing 55 IS militants|publisher=i24news|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150206072946/http://www.i24news.tv/en/news/international/middle-east/60008-150204-king-abdullah-lands-in-jordan-following-murder-of-pilot|archivedate=6 February 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The following day, Jordan launched airstrikes against IS weapons and munition warehouses and training camps. According to U.S. officials, the attacks took place near [[Raqqa]] and involved 20 Jordanian F-16s, and American refueling and radio jamming aircraft assisted. After the jets completed their mission, they overflew al-Kasasbeh's hometown of Karak while on their way back to base.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2015/02/05/shocked-jordanians-rally-behind-king-against-isis-after-video-pilot-killing/|title=Jordanian fighter jets strike hard at ISIS, pay tribute to murdered pilot|publisher=Fox News}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/world/news/article.cfm?c_id=2&objectid=11397577|title=Jordanian warplanes bomb Isis targets|work=The New Zealand Herald}}</ref> The [[Jordan Radio and Television Corporation]] aired footage shot prior to those attacks, of pilots scribbling messages onto bombs slated to be used in the strikes. "For you, the enemies of Islam," read one message. Others bore verses from the [[Quran]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.youm7.com/story/2015/2/6/%D8%A8%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%81%D9%8A%D8%AF%D9%8A%D9%88%D8%B3%D9%8A%D8%B5%D9%84%D9%89-%D9%86%D8%A7%D8%B1%D8%A7-%D8%B0%D8%A7%D8%AA-%D9%84%D9%87%D8%A8%D8%A2%D9%8A%D8%A7%D8%AA-%D9%82%D8%B1%D8%A2%D9%86%D9%8A%D8%A9-%D8%B9%D9%84%D9%89-%D8%B5%D9%88%D8%A7%D8%B1%D9%8A%D8%AE-%D8%A3%D8%B1%D8%AF%D9%86%D9%8A%D8%A9-%D9%84%D8%AF%D9%83-/2055752#.VNP_PNLF9A0 |title=بالفيديو.."سيصلى نارا ذات لهب"..آيات قرآنية على صواريخ أردنية لدك داعش |اليوم السابع |publisher=Youm7.com |date= |accessdate=6 February 2015|language=Arabic}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/jordanian-pilots-scribble-messages-isis-missiles-you-enemies-islam-1486834|title=Jordanian pilots scribble messages for Isis on missiles: 'For you, the enemies of Islam'|work=International Business Times UK}}</ref> In 3 days of bombardment, Jordanian fighter jets destroyed 56 ISIS targets and killed dozens of ISIS fighters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/jordan-approximately-7000-is-members-killed-in-strikes/|title=Jordan: Approximately 7,000 IS members killed in strikes|work=The Times of Israel|accessdate=20 January 2016}}</ref>
Several clerics, leading figures of the Islamic world and news outlets roundly condemned the killing as murder. However, IS said it could be justified through [[Islamic law]], despite cremation being illegal per Islamic law.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gayle|first1=Damien|title=Even Al-Qaeda condemn murder of Jordanian pilot as 'deviant'... and leading Muslim cleric calls for ISIS militants to be killed, crucified and have limbs 'chopped'|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2939536/Even-Al-Qaeda-condemn-murder-Jordanian-pilot-deviant-leading-Muslim-cleric-calls-ISIS-militants-killed-crucified-limbs-chopped.html|accessdate=6 February 2015|work=Daily Mail|date=4 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=I38U4bEhQmM|title=Scholar Khola Hasan on Murder of Jordanian Pilot Moaz al-Kassasbeh by ISIS|date=9 February 2015|publisher=|accessdate=20 January 2016|via=YouTube}}</ref>
The Jordanian branch of the [[Muslim Brotherhood]], the [[Islamic Action Front]], condemned the killing of al-Kasasbeh. Their statement described it as a "crime", without mentioning ISIS. The IAF's leader, Sheikh Hammam Saïd, in a 5 February interview with Radio Sawa, asked Jordan to withdraw from the anti-ISIS coalition, saying "Jordan should not be part of a coalition run by the United States."<ref name="Yoni Ben Menachem">{{cite web|url=http://jcpa.org/muslim-brotherhood-refuses-to-condemn-islamic-state|title=Muslim Brotherhood in Jordan Refuses to Condemn Islamic State for Killing Jordanian Pilot|author=Yoni Ben Menachem |publisher=Jerusalem Center for Public Affairs (JCPA)|location=Jerusalem}}</ref>
Sheikh Salam Salameh, a [[Hamas]] member of the [[Palestinian Legislative Council]] (PLC), said "IS members are, in one way or another, considered Muslims and we must not stand with the enemies of [[Allah]] against the people of Allah (the IS)." He added, "Jordan is the reason for al-Kasasbeh having been burned. It was the Jordanian government's decision to send its army into [[Syria]] to assist the [Syrian] government against the rebels in their war, in which it [Jordan] has no interest. It should have adopted a similar position to [[Turkey]]."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newsmax.com/Newsfront/Jordan-Muslim-Brotherhood-ISIS-pilot/2015/02/10/id/623890/|title=Jordan's Muslim Brotherhood Won't Condemn ISIS' Murder of Pilot|publisher=Newsmax|accessdate=20 January 2016}}</ref><ref name="Yoni Ben Menachem"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.palwatch.org/pages/news_archive.aspx?doc_id=14499|title=Hamas justifies IS' brutal murder of Jordanian pilot - Palestinian Daily News|publisher=|accessdate=20 January 2016}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
